column1: Road closed to all vehicles in both directions
United Kingdom: <ref group=note>Also used as a 'NO ENTRY' sign when used in conjunction with a plate stating some exception such as 'Except for Access'. This sign additionally automatically carries an exemption for cycles being pushed by a pedestrian.</ref>

<ref group=note>This sign can only be used if there are no exceptions. If an exception is to granted  then the 'prohibited all vehicles' sign above should be used with a plate specifying the exemptions (for example: "Except Busses"). Technically  this sign means 'NO ENTRY' to any wheeled vehicle including cycles being pushed (but not cycles being carried)  perambulators  wheeled buggies and even wheelchairs. The last three prohibitions are seldom  if ever  enforced.</ref>

Switzerland & Liechtenstein: <ref name=CHMopedImplied group=note>Always also implies mopeds with a maximum design speed of 25 km/h</ref>
United Kingdom: <ref group=note>The Traffic Signs Regulations and General Directions 2002 emphasises that enforcement of this sign is not specifically supported by any statutory regulation. However this does not prevent a cyclist from being prosecuted under the Town Police Clauses Act  1847. The cyclist can also be prosecuted under the Offences Against the Person Act  1861 (as amended by the Criminal Justice Act 1948) if anyone is injured as a result of the cyclist's presence. Both of these Victorian Acts provide for terms of imprisonment for their infringement.</ref>

Switzerland & Liechtenstein: <ref group=note>Prohibition of large goods vehicles (with total weight larger than 3.5 t  including any load).</ref>
United Kingdom: <ref group=note>The weight shown on the vehicle is the maximum permitted weight of the vehicle excluding any load</ref>

column1: No horns or excessive motor noise
Switzerland & Liechtenstein: REPLACED by sign no. 4.14 <ref group=note>This sign has been replaced by sign no. 4.14 "Hospital"  since it was only used in this context!</ref>

column1: No overtaking by heavy goods vehicles

United Kingdom: <ref group=note>The words indicate the structure that the vehicle is prohibited from (in this case a bridge). The weight shown is in (metric) tonnes.</ref>

Switzerland & Liechtenstein: <ref group=note>Applies also to axles being apart not more than 1 metre.</ref>

column1: No vehicles carrying dangerous water pollutants
Minimum safe following distance between vehicles
